etymology.description: 之(之) (zhī, "of") indicates possession or association, while 意(意) (yì, "intention") refers to a thought, will, or idea. Together, 之意 refers to the intention or thought of someone or something.
etymology.interpretation: 之(之) (zhī, "of") is a classical particle denoting possession, commonly used in literary Chinese to connect two elements. 意(意) (yì, "intention") signifies one's thought or purpose. Thus, 之意 expresses the intention or idea related to a subject.

examples.chinese: 他说这句话别有深意(他說這句話別有深意)，其中蕴藏着宽容之意(其中蘊藏著寬容之意)。
examples.pinyin: Tā shuō zhè jù huà bié yǒu shēn yì, qí zhōng yùn cáng zhe kuān róng zhī yì.
examples.english: He said that his words had a unique depth, within which lay the intention of tolerance.

examples.chinese: 老者的诗中饱含忧国之意(老者的詩中飽含憂國之意)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎo zhě de shī zhōng bǎo hán yōu guó zhī yì.
examples.english: The old poet's verses are full of the intention of national concern.
